S3.T1.caption: Table 1: Details on input robustness datasets
S3.T1.table:
Datasets Perturbation Metric QType Finetuning Dataset Evaluation
len(Q) #IQ #PER/CE #ORI/Easy
VQA-Rephrasings (Shah etÂ al., 2019) Rephrasing CS(mğ‘šm) All VQA v2 train 7.15 \eqmakebox[log][r]162k \eqmakebox[log][r]121,516 \eqmakebox[log][r]40,504
VQA P2 (Whitehead etÂ al., 2020) Par&Syn&Ant CS(mğ‘šm) All VQA v2 train 6.32 \eqmakebox[log][r]52k \eqmakebox[log][r]26,512 \eqmakebox[log][r]25,814
IV-VQA (Agarwal etÂ al., 2020) Invariant object #flips All VQA v2 train 5.85 \eqmakebox[log][r]120k \eqmakebox[log][r]83,700 \eqmakebox[log][r]36,181
CV-VQA (Agarwal etÂ al., 2020) Covariant object #flips Num VQA v2 train 5.83 \eqmakebox[log][r]4k \eqmakebox[log][r]4,141 \eqmakebox[log][r]2,641
VQA-CE (Dancette etÂ al., 2021) Counterexample - All VQA v2 train 6.19 \eqmakebox[log][r]214k \eqmakebox[log][r]63,298 \eqmakebox[log][r]147,681
references:
TableÂ 1 summarizes dataset details, including the type of perturbation, specific evaluation metrics for robustness, question type (QType), shared dataset for finetuning, and the test datasets statistics.
These statistics encompass the total number of image-question pairs (#IQ), perturbation samples (#PER/CE), original samples (#ORI/Easy), and the average question length (len(Q)).
Specifically, VQA-Rephrasings averagely collects 3 rephrasings for each of the 40,504 questions sampled from the VQA v2 validation set, resulting in approximately 162k image-question pairs.
VQA P2 creates three types of linguistic perturbations, i.e.,Â sentence rephrasing (Par), and word substitution with synonyms (Syn) or antonyms (Ant), for 25,814 sampled questions, ultimately obtaining roughly about 52k image-question pairs.
IV-VQA employs a GAN-based resynthesis technique to remove objects irrelevant to the given question from the image, such that object removal does not affect the answer.
Conversely, CV-VQA focuses on counting questions (Num) and removes one relevant object, causing the predicted answer on the number of objects to be reduced by one.
In total, IV-VQA and CV-VQA contain approximately 120k and 4k image-question pairs, respectively.
VQA-CE is an evaluation benchmark for multimodal shortcuts involved in images and questions.
It utilizes the detected shortcuts from the training set to obtain 63,298 counterexamples, where all shortcuts lead to incorrect answers, from the VQA v2 validation set.
Additionally, VQA-CE constructs 147,681 easy examples in which at least one shortcut provides the correct answer.

S3.T2.table:

OOD VL-BERTBB{}_{\text{B}} (Su etÂ al., 2020) single-stream CC Region Feature AC
ID+OOD VL-T5 (Cho etÂ al., 2021) encoder-decoder COCO,VG,GQA,VQA,VGQA Region Feature TG

UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}} (Chen etÂ al., 2020) single-stream COCO,VG,SUB,CC Region Feature AC
ALBEF (Li etÂ al., 2021) encoder-decoder COCO,VG,SUB,CC Patch Embedding TG
mPLUGBB{}_{\text{B}} (Li etÂ al., 2022) encoder-decoder COCO,VG,SBU,CC,CC12M Patch Embedding TG

references:
As summarized in TableÂ 2, we utilize nine pretrained VLMs with three typical transformer architectures as baselines to evaluate the input robustness of our method.
Specifically, VisualBERT (Li etÂ al., 2019), VL-BERTBB{}_{\text{B}} (Su etÂ al., 2020), and UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}} (Chen etÂ al., 2020) employ single-stream encoders.
LXMERT (Tan and Bansal, 2019), ViLBERT (Lu etÂ al., 2019), and BEiT-3BB{}_{\text{B}} (Wang etÂ al., 2023) utilize two-stream encoders.
VL-T5 (Cho etÂ al., 2021), ALBEF (Li etÂ al., 2021), and mPLUGBB{}_{\text{B}} (Li etÂ al., 2022) incorporate encoder-decoder architectures.
When applied to the downstream VQA task, mPLUGBB{}_{\text{B}}, VL-T5, and ALBEF formulate VQA as a text generation task (TG), while the remaining baselines formulate VQA as a multi-answer classification problem (AC).
These baselines adopt two typical image tokens, namely, the region feature extracted by a pretrained object detector and the patch embedding obtained using a linear projection, and are pretrained on large-scale image-text (IT) data to learn task-agnostic versatile representations.

The pretraining IT datasets include MS COCO caption (COCO) (Chen etÂ al., 2015), Visual Genome (VG) (Krishna etÂ al., 2017), VQA v2 (VQA) (Goyal etÂ al., 2017), GQA balance version (GQA) (Hudson and Manning, 2019), VG-QA (VGQA) (Zhu etÂ al., 2016), Conceptual Captions (CC) (Sharma etÂ al., 2018), SBU captions (SBU) (Ordonez etÂ al., 2011), and Conceptual 12M (CC12M) (Changpinyo etÂ al., 2021).
Since VQA v2 images originate from the COCO dataset, we follow the work (Chen etÂ al., 2020) to categorize these pretrained VLMs into in-domain (ID), in-domain and out-of-domain (ID+OOD), and out-of-domain (OOD) groups based on whether they utilize the COCO dataset during the pretraining process.

In the subsequent experiments, we maintain the initial configurations of all pretrained VLMs. The region features (visual inputs) of VisualBERT, VL-T5, LXMERT, UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}}, ViLBERT, and VL-BERTBB{}_{\text{B}} are extracted using BUA Faster R-CNN (Anderson etÂ al., 2018) pretrained on VG (Krishna etÂ al., 2017).
The representation dimension dğ‘‘d is set to 768.

The configurations of the number of word tokens Lğ¿L (i.e.,Â the maximum token length allowed for a question) and image tokens Kğ¾K are detailed in TableÂ 3.
For the only crucial hyperparameter Î²ğ›½\beta in Eq.Â (6), it is set to 1Ã—10âˆ’41superscript1041\times 10^{-4} in all cases except for finetuning VisualBERT and LXMERT, where Î²ğ›½\beta is set to 5Ã—10âˆ’55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}.
All experiments, except those on ALBEF, BEiT-3BB{}_{\text{B}}, and mPLUGBB{}_{\text{B}} implemented on one NVIDIA A100 40GB GPU, are conducted using PyTorch on one NVIDIA GTX2080Ti 12GB GPU.
We uniformly utilize an AdamW optimizer with a linear warmup using linear decay and a warmup step of 1000.
The number of finetuning epochs is 10.
The configurations of batch size and peak learning rate for each pretrained VLM are shown TableÂ 3.

The best model is selected based on the VQA-Score on the mini-split of VQA v2 training set that excludes image-question pairs when evaluating input robustness.

To evaluate the effectiveness of CIB against linguistic variations, with CIB as the training objective, we finetune pretrained VLMs on VQA v2 training split and report results on VQA-Rephrasings and VQA P2.
TableÂ 4 and TableÂ 5 show the comparisons with existing methods in terms of the VQA-Score as well as the robustness metric of CS(mğ‘šm).

Result on VQA-Rephrasings.
We first compare the proposed CIB with existing methods: CC (Shah etÂ al., 2019), ConClaT (Kant etÂ al., 2021), and MANGO (Li etÂ al., 2020).
Specifically, both CC and ConClaT augment training datasets online by training a question generation model to generate paraphrases of questions.
To effectively leverage augmented data and enhance model robustness to linguistic variations, CC considers cycle consistency between the question and its rephrasings, while ConClaT jointly optimizes contrastive and cross-entropy losses.
CC considers three baseline VQA models, i.e.,Â BUTD (Anderson etÂ al., 2018), Pythia (Jiang etÂ al., 2018), and BAN (Kim etÂ al., 2018).
ConClaT uses MMT (Kant etÂ al., 2021), a modified version of UNITER, as its baseline.
MANGO employs UNITER (Chen etÂ al., 2020) and VILLA (Gan etÂ al., 2020) as baseline models and adopts adversarial training to enhance model robustness.
As shown in TableÂ 4, 111VL-T5 and LXMERT utilize some examples from the VQA v2 validation set in the pretraining VQA task, resulting in an unreliable VQA-Score for ORI, thus we do not report the ORI performance. the results on nine pretrained VLMs consistently show that compared to baselines (i.e.,Â finetuning pretrained VLMs with only the task-related loss for answer predictionâ€ ), using CIB as the training objective for VQA models can significantly improve their robustness to linguistic variations.
This finding suggests that it is feasible to encourage models to learn more compact and robust representations from an information-theoretic perspective.
In comparison with state-of-the-art methods, adapting LXMERT with CIB achieves the best performance across all metrics.
This performance advantage can be attributed to LXMERT considering the VQA training objective during pretraining, which reduces the gap between upstream and downstream objectives. 
In addition, we observe that the data augmentation based method (CC) yields greater improvements in the metric of CS(4).
However, without data augmentation, the average improvement of our method is more substantial.

To evaluate the effectiveness of CIB against linguistic variations, with CIB as the training objective, we finetune pretrained VLMs on VQA v2 training split and report results on VQA-Rephrasings and VQA P2.
TableÂ 4 and TableÂ 5 show the comparisons with existing methods in terms of the VQA-Score as well as the robustness metric of CS(mğ‘šm).

Result on VQA P2.
We next compare our method with the existing method Q3R (Whitehead etÂ al., 2020) on VQA P2.
Q3R augments training data by creating linguistic variations such as synonymous, paraphrastic, and antonymous of input questions, and regularizes the visual reasoning process between the question and its generated questions.
Q3R utilizes three baseline models: StackNMN (Hu etÂ al., 2018), HybridNet (Whitehead etÂ al., 2020), and XNM (Shi etÂ al., 2019).
The results in TableÂ 5 indicate that finetuning pretrained VLMs with the proposed CIB can markedly improve their robustness against question variations on VQA P2.
Moreover, finetuning LXMERT with CIB also achieves the best performance on VQA P2.
In addition, the data augmentation-based method (Q3R) continues to exhibit superiority in improving the input robustness of baseline VQA models.

references:
We evaluate the robustness of our method against visual variations on IV-VQA and CV-VQA.
TableÂ 6 shows the comparisons with existing methods in the metrics of VQA-Score and #flips.
CL (a simple CNN+LSTM model) (Lu etÂ al., 2015), SNMN (an attention-based method) (Hu etÂ al., 2018), and SAAA (a compositional model) (Kazemi and Elqursh, 2017) are benchmarked by AgarwalÂ etÂ al. (Agarwal etÂ al., 2020).
MANGO exploits adversarial training to improve the robustness of pretrained VLMs (UNITER (Chen etÂ al., 2020) and VILLA (Gan etÂ al., 2020)) against visual variations.
The results in TableÂ 6 show that significant improvements are achieved across all metrics and baselines on both IV-VQA and CV-VQA, suggesting the effectiveness of CIB in improving robustness against visual variations.

Moreover, we observe that pretrained VLMs using raw images as visual inputs (e.g.,Â BEiT-3BB{}_{\text{B}}, mPLUGBB{}_{\text{B}}, and ALBEF) exhibit superior performance in defending against visual variations compared to those pretrained VLMs (e.g.,Â VisualBERT, LXMERT, and UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}}) that employ object-level region features as visual inputs.
This can be attributed to the fact that pre-extracted region features lose some image information, which hinders VQA models in comprehending and retrieving visual content according to a given question.

To demonstrate the ability of CIB to defend against multimodal shortcuts present in input images and questions, we conduct experiments on VQA-CE and compare our methods with existing approaches.
Results are summarized in TableÂ 7.
The compared methods in the table can be broadly classified into two groups: (i) plain models (SAN (Yang etÂ al., 2016), BLOCK (Ben-Younes etÂ al., 2019), VilBERT (Lu etÂ al., 2019), and BUTD (Anderson etÂ al., 2018)), and (ii) bias-reduction methods (RUBi (Cadene etÂ al., 2019), LMH + RMFE (Gat etÂ al., 2020), ESR (Shrestha etÂ al., 2020), LMH (Clark etÂ al., 2019), LfF (Nam etÂ al., 2020), LMH + CSS (Chen etÂ al., 2020), and RandImg (Teney etÂ al., 2020)).
These experimental results are cited from the work (Dancette etÂ al., 2021).
As shown in TableÂ 7, finetuning baseline pretrained VLMs with CIB achieves significant improvements and outperforms bias-reduction methods by a considerable margin, particularly on counterexamples.
These results suggest that the proposed CIB is more effective at alleviating the spurious correlations between representations and reducing shortcut learning involved in multimodal inputs.

When finetuning pretrained VLMs with CIB, Iâ€‹(Y;T)ğ¼ğ‘Œğ‘‡I(Y;T) is regarded as the task-related objective, while Iâ€‹(Xv,Xl;Tv,Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{v},X^{l};T^{v},T^{l}) serves as a MI regularizer to constrain representation compactness and pursue more robust representations.
As stated in TheoremÂ 3.1, the upper bound of Iâ€‹(Xv,Xl;Tv,Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{v},X^{l};T^{v},T^{l}) consists of four terms: Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£I(X^{v};T^{v}), Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{l};T^{l}), âˆ’Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™-I(T^{v};T^{l}), and Dsklsubscriptğ·sklD_{\text{skl}}.
To analyze the contribution of different terms to CIB, we perform an ablation study on different meaningful combinations of these terms, that is, provable upper bounds of Iâ€‹(Xv,Xl;Tv,Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{v},X^{l};T^{v},T^{l}), on VQA-Rephrasings using LXMERT, UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}}, and ALBEF as baseline pretrained VLMs.
Specifically, the regularizer upper bound has three other meaningful alternatives:
(i) 32â€‹[Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)+Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)]32delimited-[]ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™\frac{3}{2}[I(X^{v};T^{v})+I(X^{l};T^{l})],
(ii) âˆ’Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)+Dsklğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ·skl-I(T^{v};T^{l})+D_{\text{skl}}, and
(iii) Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)+Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)+Dsklğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ·sklI(X^{v};T^{v})+I(X^{l};T^{l})+D_{\text{skl}}
(cf.Â SectionÂ A.2 for proofs).
TableÂ 8 presents results on VQA-Rephrasings.
Overall, the ablation results on different bounds are consistent, indicating that CIB with any meaningful upper bounds can markedly improve the performance of baseline pretrained VLMs.
However, CIB with our derived upper bound performs best, empirically demonstrating that the bound in TheoremÂ 3.1 is a tighter and more precise bound.
Furthermore, the comparison between upper bound (iii) Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)+Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)+Dsklğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ·sklI(X^{v};T^{v})+I(X^{l};T^{l})+D_{\text{skl}} and our upper bound Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)+Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)âˆ’Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)+Dsklğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™subscriptğ·sklI(X^{v};T^{v})+I(X^{l};T^{l})-I(T^{v};T^{l})+D_{\text{skl}} suggests that CIB can effectively facilitate the correlation between visual and linguistic representations and modality alignment by maximizing Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(T^{v};T^{l}).

In practice, any sample-based upper bound estimator of MI can be utilized to approximate Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£I(X^{v};T^{v}) and Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{l};T^{l}), and any differentiable MI lower bound estimator can be applied to approach Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(T^{v};T^{l}).
To analyze the impact of different MI estimators on CIB, we consider the following experimental settings:
(i) We alternately utilize L1Out (Poole etÂ al., 2019) instead of CLUB (Cheng etÂ al., 2020) as the estimator of MI upper bound to approximate Iâ€‹(Xv;Tv)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£I(X^{v};T^{v}) and Iâ€‹(Xl;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘™superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(X^{l};T^{l}).
(ii) We approximate Iâ€‹(Tv;Tl)ğ¼superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™I(T^{v};T^{l}) with the three other estimators of MI lower bound, i.e.,Â InfoNCE (Oord etÂ al., 2018), NWJ (Nguyen etÂ al., 2010), and MINE (Belghazi etÂ al., 2018).
TableÂ 9 presents comparisons between different MI estimators on VQA-Rephrasings using LXMERT, UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}}, and ALBEF as baselines.
These results consistently demonstrate that CIB can effectively improve the performance of baselines with different transformer architectures and that the effectiveness of CIB does not depend on a specific MI estimator.

As illustrated in Fig.Â 1(b), for pretrained VLMs with two-stream encoders (e.g.,Â LXMERT and ViLBERT), there is an alternative option for internal representations, i.e.,Â T=[Tvâ€²,Tlâ€²]ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ‘£â€²superscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ‘™â€²T=[T^{{}^{\prime}v},T^{{}^{\prime}l}], which are the visual and linguistic representations after the vision transformer layers (fÎ¸VTransubscriptğ‘“superscriptğœƒVTranf_{\theta^{\text{VTran}}}) and language transformer layers (fÎ¸LTransubscriptğ‘“superscriptğœƒLTranf_{\theta^{\text{LTran}}}).

TableÂ 10 shows the VQA-Score for PER on VQA-Rephrasings, revealing that different internal representations have a slight impact on the PER performance of CIB.

references:
To analyze the impact of CIB on standard VQA performance (i.e.,Â whether the representation compression impairs the standard VQA performance), we utilize CIB as the objective to train the aforementioned baseline pretrained VLMs on the VQA v2 training and validation sets.
The results on VQA v2 test-dev are shown in TableÂ 11.
222
Since we do not utilize the additional question-answer pairs from VG (Krishna etÂ al., 2017) for data augmentation in our experiments and some other detail differences, there are minor differences between our re-implementationâ€  of the baseline pretrained VLMs and the published results in the original papers.
Overall, training baseline pretrained VLMs with the proposed CIB can slightly improve the standard VQA performance.
In particular, the performance improvement of VisualBERT and ALBEF is relatively significant.
This because that their visual inputs contain more redundant information, such as image background and visual content irrelevant to the given question (VisualBERT and ALBEF respectively adopt 100 region-level features and 900 patch-level features as visual inputs).
Therefore, our hypothesis is that a certain degree of compression of representations can reduce the redundant information learned from inputs and make the obtained representations more compact and robust.

Noting that, in contrast to the significant improvement in input robustness, CIB leads to relatively limited improvement in standard performance.
This observation also indirectly indicates that the proposed CIB is carefully designed and tailored to improve input robustness when adapting pretrained VLMs for the downstream VQA.

For (i), as proposed in the work (Ban and Dong, 2022), we consider three different ways for perturbation generation, i.e.,Â L4Abasebase{}_{\text{base}}, L4Afusefuse{}_{\text{fuse}}, and L4Augsugs{}_{\text{ugs}}.
Before finetuning the pretrained ALBEF with a text generation loss and the proposed CIB as a training objective, we first utilize the three methods above to generate PAPs by lifting the neuron activations of low-level layers of the ALBEF.
Next, we separately add the generated PAPs to input images and finetune the pretrained ALBEF on the VQA v2 training and validation sets, and test their performance on VQA v2 test-dev.
Fig.Â 4 shows the performance comparison, where the blue bar marked with red performance indicates the VQA-Score drop with respect to the standard performance under an attack.
From the figure, we can observe that CIB markedly reduces the performance drop, demonstrating its ability to better alleviate the vulnerability of VQA models to such attacks.
For (ii), following the experimental setups for evaluating input robustness, we first finetune pretrained UNITERBB{}_{\text{B}} and LXMERT on the standard and clean VQA v2 training set, and then evaluate human-adversarial robustness on the adversarial benchmark AdVQA.
As shown in TableÂ 12, the significant performance improvement of our method over baselines demonstrates the robustness of CIB against human-adversarial attacks.
In summary, the aforementioned experiments consistently suggest that the proposed CIB, as a generic objective, can potentially alleviate the vulnerability of models to adversarial attacks when adapting pretrained VLMs to downstream tasks.

Â Â Â Â Â â€ƒ+ CIB 59.41 67.39 47.18
references:
The proposed CIB is essentially a generic training objective that can be applied to various multimodal tasks beyond the VQA task.
To evaluate the generalizability of CIB to other multimodal tasks, we consider the task of weakly-supervised visual grounding.
Following the original experimental setups of ALBEF (Li etÂ al., 2021), we finetune pretrained ALBEF with CIB on the RefCOCO+ (Yu etÂ al., 2016) training dataset in a weakly-supervised setups, i.e.,Â finetuning models using only image-text supervision without bounding box annotations.
From the results in TableÂ 13, we find that using CIB as the training objective can further improve the performance of the baseline ALBEFitmitm{}_{\text{itm}}, demonstrating that the proposed CIB can be effectively applied to other multimodal tasks.
